image.altText: A man holding a baby and a crying girl walk past a police officer in a helmet

items.synopsis: A combination of old-fashioned espionage and high-tech surveillance was meant to keep Israelis safe. But when Hamas smashed through the fence, all the systems seemed to fail.

title.children: Paragliders, kidnappings and rockets: How did Hamas pull off such an audacious attack?

image.altText: Fire and smoke rise following an Israeli airstrike, in Gaza City.

items.synopsis: As the death toll from Hamas attacks on Israel and counterstrikes in Gaza climbs, Israel officially declares war and vows to attack Hamas targets.

title.children: Israel formally declares war and says 'significant military steps' to be taken

image.altText: A woman in a 'DISRUPT BURRUP HUB' T-shirt stands in the street with her arms raised

items.synopsis: The battle over the climate is escalating, and nowhere more than in Western Australia, where a new generation of protesters is prepared to break the law to make their point.

title.children: Tilda will remember this day for the rest of her life. It's the day she broke the law

image.altText: Three mature-aged women stand laughing and smiling

items.synopsis: A cruel and incurable disease took former TV personality Fiona MacDonald's voice, and her trademark quick wit and banter with it. But she's not staying silent.

title.children: 'There is no treatment, no cure': Why Fiona MacDonald is making every second count

image.altText: A close up photo of a man in a blue jacket holding a silver whistle

items.synopsis: Institutions that do the wrong thing usually do what they can to cover it up. That’s the force a whistleblower is up against, writes Adele Ferguson.

title.children: Lost jobs, failed marriages, freedom at risk: Whistleblowers take huge risks at great personal cost

image.altText: A group of men in dark uniforms wearing helmets and holding military-style rifles stand beside an armoured vehicle on a road.

items.synopsis: Israel says it is at war as its soldiers battle Hamas fighters in the streets of southern Israel and launch air strikes on Gaza. Follow live.

title.children: As death toll passes 1,000, Gaza residents tell of ‘unbearable' fear and terror

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Israeli rescue service Zaka says its paramedics have removed about 260 bodies from a music festival attended by thousands that came under attack by Hamas militants. The total figure is expected to be higher as other paramedic teams were working in the area. Video aired on social media and by Israeli news outlets showed dozens of festival goers running through an open field as gunshots rang out. Many hid in nearby fruit orchards or were gunned down as they fled.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: At least 260 bodies recovered from music festival, Israeli Rescue Service says

children.content: The Israeli rescue service Zaka says its paramedics have removed
about 260 bodies
from a music festival attended by thousands that came under attack by
Hamas
militants.
The total figure is
expected to be higher
as other paramedic teams were working in the area.
Video aired on social media and by Israeli news outlets showed dozens of festival goers running through an open field as gunshots rang out.
Many hid in nearby fruit orchards or were gunned down as they fled.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Speaking in Melbourne this morning, Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia unequivocally condemned the attack on Israel by Hamas. "Australia's thoughts are with those lost, those injured, those taken hostage and all their loved ones," she said. "Australia always urges the protection of civilian lives." She says Australia is seeking to confirm the welfare of Australians in affected areas and is working with local authorities. "We urge Australians who are in Israel, if you have not done so, to please contact your families to assure us all of your safety," she says. "I don't have any information at this stage of Australians hospitalised or injured or any fatalities but we are seeking to ascertain the welfare of Australians on the ground." She says travel advice has been altered for Australians to a do not travel for Gaza and near the border.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Penny Wong condemns attack on Israel, calls for Australians to contact loved ones

children.content: Speaking in Melbourne this morning, Foreign Minister Penny Wong said Australia
unequivocally condemned the attack on Israel by Hamas.
"Australia's thoughts are with those lost, those injured, those taken hostage and all their loved ones," she said.
"Australia always urges the protection of civilian lives."
She says Australia is seeking to confirm the welfare of Australians in affected areas and is working with local authorities.
"We urge Australians who are in Israel, if you have not done so, to please contact your families to assure us all of your safety," she says.
"I don't have any information at this stage of Australians hospitalised or injured or any fatalities but we are seeking to ascertain the welfare of Australians on the ground."
She says travel advice has been altered for Australians to a do not travel for Gaza and near the border.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Ameera Harouda Gaza resident Maher Saeed Elyan, 58, told the ABC he hoped everything would be OK, but that residents were scared. "Last night [Saturday night] was extremely difficult, filled with tension and fear for children and women, and we couldn't sleep," he said. "The feeling was one of terror and fear that was unbearable. Both children and adults were feeling afraid. The Israeli occupation aims to instil fear and terror in the hearts of the citizens" When asked whether residents will abide by Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's statement demanding they leave Gaza, Mr Saeed Elyan said the prime minister "is dreaming" and that residents will never leave. "We've been displaced once and twice, but this time, no. This will not happen. I am a refugee from Jaffa. I will not go anywhere. Will I go to Sinai? This will not happen. We will not leave our homes even if our homes are targeted and bombed."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: People in Gaza 'filled with fear'

children.content: Reporting by Ameera Harouda
Gaza resident Maher Saeed Elyan, 58, told the ABC he hoped everything would be OK, but that residents were scared.
"Last night [Saturday night] was extremely difficult, filled with tension and fear for children and women, and we couldn't sleep," he said.
"The feeling was one of terror and fear that was unbearable. Both children and adults were feeling afraid. The Israeli occupation aims to instil fear and terror in the hearts of the citizens"

props.alt: Two men sitting on concrete outside a building

children.content: (ABC News: Ameera Harouda)
When asked whether residents will abide by
Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's
statement demanding they leave Gaza, Mr Saeed Elyan said the prime minister "is dreaming" and that residents will never leave.

"We've been displaced once and twice, but this time, no. This will not happen. I am a refugee from Jaffa. I will not go anywhere. Will I go to Sinai? This will not happen. We will not leave our homes even if our homes are targeted and bombed."

props.alt: Two men sitting on concrete outside a building, seen from a distance

children.content: (ABC News; Ameera Harouda)

title.children: Conspiracy theories, 'anger' and a flow towards No. Here's what it's like on the campaign frontline

image.altText: Colleen Johnstone and Phil Bayley with their son Angus using a laptop computer.

items.synopsis: Angus isn't like most other year 11 students — it takes him a lot longer to read and understand information. His school gave him extra time at his mid-year exams which really helped. The trouble is, at finals, he won't get anywhere near that — and experts say that isn't fair.

title.children: Angus needs more time in exams to help his 'brain think', but he won't get it at his finals — and advocates say that's unfair

image.altText: Vilimoni Botitu runs with the ball

items.synopsis: The Wallabies need Portugal to beat Fiji to have any chance of making the Rugby World Cup quarterfinals. Follow all the action in our live blog.

title.children: Portugal lead against Fiji as Wallabies watch on

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The lineout was brilliant - the maul was unstoppable and big prop Francisco Fernandes burrows over to give Portugal the lead again! Wow wow wow wow wow. Samuel Marques nails the conversion and Portugal lead 17-10!
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 51' PORTUGAL SCORE ANOTHER!

children.content: (Getty Images)
The lineout was brilliant - the maul was unstoppable and big prop Francisco Fernandes burrows over to give Portugal the lead again!
Wow wow wow wow wow.
Samuel Marques nails the conversion and Portugal lead 17-10!

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Big moment in this game. A big step from Rodrigo Marta got Levani Botia into an awkward position and he's clocked him on the chin with his forehead. It's high, it's a yellow card, and the bunker will keep looking at it. The Portuguese kick for touch from the penalty.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 50' Levani Botia sent to the sin bin!

children.content: Big moment in this game.
A big step from Rodrigo Marta got Levani Botia into an awkward position and he's clocked him on the chin with his forehead.
It's high, it's a yellow card, and the bunker will keep looking at it.
The Portuguese kick for touch from the penalty.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Levani Botia dots down off the back of that Fijian pressure. A brilliant response from the Fijians. Botia picked up the ball at the base of a ruck and just have to reach out to score. The kick is good, we're back on level terms at 10-10.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 48' Try Fiji!

children.content: Levani Botia dots down off the back of that Fijian pressure.
A brilliant response from the Fijians.
Botia picked up the ball at the base of a ruck and just have to reach out to score.
The kick is good, we're back on level terms at 10-10.
